title: EM waves - acceleration direction of electron

content.question: An electron is initially at rest, far away from other charged objects. An electromagnetic wave approaches the electron, traveling in the positive <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>z</mi></math>-direction. Immediately after the wave reaches the electron, which of the following gives a possible direction of the electronâ€™s acceleration and provides evidence that supports the claim?

choices.label: Parallel to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. Electromagnetic waves are transverse waves.
Parallel to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. Electromagnetic waves are longitudinal waves.
Parallel to the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>z</mi></math>-axis. Electromagnetic waves are transverse waves.
Parallel to the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>z</mi></math>-axis. Electromagnetic waves are longitudinal waves.

content.answer: Parallel to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. Electromagnetic waves are transverse waves.
